pli-tv-bu-vb-pd1:0.2: The monks’ rules and their analysis
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd1:0.3: The chapter on offenses entailing acknowledgment
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd1:0.4: 1. The first training rule on acknowledgment
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd1:0.5: Venerables, these four rules on acknowledgment come up for recitation.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd1:1.1: At one time when the Buddha was staying at Sāvatthī in Anāthapiṇḍika’s Monastery,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd1:1.2: there was a nun who was returning from almsround in Sāvatthī. She saw a monk and said to him,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd1:1.4: Saying, “Very well, Sister,” he took everything.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd1:1.5: But because the time for eating was coming to an end, she was not able to go for alms, and she missed her meal.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd1:1.7: and the following day the same thing happened again.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd1:1.11: On the fourth day that nun was walking along a street, trembling.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd1:1.12: A prominent merchant in a carriage who was coming in the opposite direction saw that nun and said to her,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd1:1.14: As she stepped aside, she collapsed right there.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd1:1.15: The merchant then asked her for forgiveness:
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd1:1.16: “Forgive me, Venerable, since you fell because of me.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd1:1.20: The nun told that merchant what had happened.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd1:1.21: He then brought her to his house and gave her a meal, and afterwards he complained and criticized the monks,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd1:1.22: “How can the venerables receive food from the hand of a nun?
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd1:1.23: It’s difficult for women to get material support.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd1:1.24: The monks heard the complaints of that prominent merchant,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd1:1.25: and the monks of few desires complained and criticized that monk,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd1:1.26: “How can a monk receive food from the hand of a nun?” …
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd1:1.27: “Is it true, monk, that you did this?”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd1:1.31: “Foolish man, a man and a woman who are not related don’t know what’s appropriate and what’s inappropriate in dealing with each other, what’s right and what’s wrong.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd1:1.32: And still you received food from the hand of an unrelated nun.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd1:1.33: This won’t give rise to confidence in those without it …
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd1:1.34: And, monks, this training rule should be recited thus:
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd1:1.35: ‘If a monk personally receives staple or non-staple food from the hand of an unrelated nun who has entered an inhabited area, and then eats it, he must acknowledge it:
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd1:1.36: “I have done a blameworthy and unsuitable thing which is to be acknowledged. I acknowledge it.”’”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd1:2.1.4: … The monk who has been given the full ordination by a unanimous Sangha through a legal procedure consisting of one motion and three announcements that is irreversible and fit to stand—this sort of monk is meant in this case.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd1:2.1.6: anyone who is not a descendant of one’s male ancestors going back seven generations, either on the mother’s side or on the father’s side.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd1:2.1.8: she has been given the full ordination by both Sanghas.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd1:2.1.10: a street, a cul-de-sac, an intersection, a house.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd1:2.1.12: apart from the five staple foods, the post-midday tonics, the seven-day tonics, and the lifetime tonics, the rest is called “non-staple food”.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd1:2.1.14: there are five kinds of staple food: cooked grain, porridge, flour, fish, and meat.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd1:2.1.15: If he receives the food with the intention of eating it, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd1:2.1.16: For every mouthful, he commits an offense entailing acknowledgment.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd1:2.2.1: If she is unrelated and he perceives her as unrelated, and he personally receives staple or non-staple food from her hand when she has entered an inhabited area, and then eats it, he commits an offense entailing acknowledgment.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd1:2.2.2: If she is unrelated, but he is unsure of it, and he personally receives staple or non-staple food from her hand when she has entered an inhabited area, and then eats it, he commits an offense entailing acknowledgment.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd1:2.2.3: If she is unrelated, but he perceives her as related, and he personally receives staple or non-staple food from her hand when she has entered an inhabited area, and then eats it, he commits an offense entailing acknowledgment.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd1:2.2.4: If he receives post-midday tonics, seven-day tonics, or lifetime tonics for the purpose of food, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd1:2.2.5: For every mouthful, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd1:2.2.6: If he receives staple or non-staple food, with the intention of eating it, from the hand of a nun who is fully ordained only on one side,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd1:2.2.7: he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd1:2.2.8: For every mouthful, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd1:2.2.9: If she is related, but he perceives her as unrelated, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd1:2.2.10: If she is related, but he is unsure if she is, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd1:2.2.11: If she is related, and he perceives her as related, there is no offense.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd1:2.3.3: if she gets someone to give it and does not give directly;
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd1:2.3.4: if she gives by placing it near;
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd1:2.3.5: if it is inside a monastery;
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd1:2.3.6: if it is at the dwelling place of nuns;
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd1:2.3.7: if it is at the dwelling place of the ascetics of another sect;
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd1:2.3.8: if it is when she is returning to the monastery;
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd1:2.3.9: if she gives after carrying it out of the village;
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd1:2.3.10: if she gives post-midday tonics, seven-day tonics, or lifetime tonics, saying, “When there’s a reason, make use of these”;
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd1:2.3.11: if it is a trainee nun;
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd1:2.3.12: if it is a novice nun;
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd1:2.3.14: if he is the first offender.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd1:2.3.15: The first training rule on acknowledgment is finished.
